segment.source: Display a splash screen for more time
segment.target: Display a splash screen for more time

segment.source: Display a splash screen for more time by creating an extended splash screen for your app.
segment.target: Display a splash screen for more time by creating an extended splash screen for your app.

segment.source: This extended screen imitates the splash screen shown when your app is launched, but can be customized.
segment.target: This extended screen imitates the splash screen shown when your app is launched, but can be customized.

segment.source: Display a splash screen for more time
segment.target: Display a splash screen for more time

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: SplashScreen class
segment.target: SplashScreen class

segment.target: Window.SizeChanged event

segment.target: Application.OnLaunched method

segment.source: Display a splash screen for more time by creating an extended splash screen for your app.
segment.target: Display a splash screen for more time by creating an extended splash screen for your app.

segment.source: This extended screen imitates the splash screen shown when your app is launched, but can be customized.
segment.target: This extended screen imitates the splash screen shown when your app is launched, but can be customized.

segment.source: Whether you want to show real-time loading information or simply give your app extra time to prepare its initial UI, an extended splash screen lets you define the launch experience.
segment.target: Whether you want to show real-time loading information or simply give your app extra time to prepare its initial UI, an extended splash screen lets you define the launch experience.

segment.source: Note The phrase "extended splash screen" in this topic refers to a splash screen that stays on the screen for an extended period of time.
segment.target: Note The phrase "extended splash screen" in this topic refers to a splash screen that stays on the screen for an extended period of time.

segment.source: It does not mean a subclass that derives from the SplashScreen class.
segment.target: It does not mean a subclass that derives from the SplashScreen class.

segment.source: Make sure your extended splash screen accurately imitates the default splash screen by following these recommendations:
segment.target: Make sure your extended splash screen accurately imitates the default splash screen by following these recommendations:

segment.source: Your extended splash screen page should use a 620 x 300 pixel image that is consistent with the image specified for your splash screen in your app manifest (your app's splash screen image).
segment.target: Your extended splash screen page should use a 620 x 300 pixel image that is consistent with the image specified for your splash screen in your app manifest (your app's splash screen image).

segment.source: In Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, splash screen settings are stored in the Splash Screen section of the Visual Assets tab in your app manifest (Package.appxmanifest file).
segment.target: In Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, splash screen settings are stored in the Splash Screen section of the Visual Assets tab in your app manifest (Package.appxmanifest file).

segment.source: Your extended splash screen should use a background color that is consistent with the background color specified for your splash screen in your app manifest (your app's splash screen background).
segment.target: Your extended splash screen should use a background color that is consistent with the background color specified for your splash screen in your app manifest (your app's splash screen background).

segment.source: Your code should use the SplashScreen class to position your app's splash screen image at the same screen coordinates as the default splash screen.
segment.target: Your code should use the SplashScreen class to position your app's splash screen image at the same screen coordinates as the default splash screen.

segment.source: Your code should respond to window resize events (such as when the screen is rotated or your app is moved next to another app onscreen) by using the SplashScreen class to reposition items on your extended splash screen.
segment.target: Your code should respond to window resize events (such as when the screen is rotated or your app is moved next to another app onscreen) by using the SplashScreen class to reposition items on your extended splash screen.

segment.source: Use the following steps to create an extended splash screen that effectively imitates the default splash screen.
segment.target: Use the following steps to create an extended splash screen that effectively imitates the default splash screen.

segment.source: Add a Blank Page item to your existing app
segment.target: Add a Blank Page item to your existing app

segment.source: This topic assumes you want to add an extended splash screen to an existing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project using C#, Visual Basic, or C++.
segment.target: This topic assumes you want to add an extended splash screen to an existing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project using C#, Visual Basic, or C++.

segment.source: Open your app in Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Open your app in Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Press or open Project from the menu bar and click Add New Item.
segment.target: Press or open Project from the menu bar and click Add New Item.

segment.source: An Add New Item dialog box will appear.
segment.target: An Add New Item dialog box will appear.

segment.source: From this dialog box, add a new Blank Page to your app.
segment.target: From this dialog box, add a new Blank Page to your app.

segment.source: This topic names the extended splash screen page "ExtendedSplash".
segment.target: This topic names the extended splash screen page "ExtendedSplash".

segment.source: Adding a Blank Page item generates two files, one for markup (ExtendedSplash.xaml) and another for code (ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs).
segment.target: Adding a Blank Page item generates two files, one for markup (ExtendedSplash.xaml) and another for code (ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs).

segment.source: Essential XAML for an extended splash screen
segment.target: Essential XAML for an extended splash screen

segment.source: Follow these steps to add an image and progress control to your extended splash screen.
segment.target: Follow these steps to add an image and progress control to your extended splash screen.

segment.source: In your ExtendedSplash.xaml file:
segment.target: In your ExtendedSplash.xaml file:

segment.source: Change the Background property of the default Grid element to match the background color you set for your app's splash screen in your app manifest (in the Visual Assets section of your Package.appxmanifest file).
segment.target: Change the Background property of the default Grid element to match the background color you set for your app's splash screen in your app manifest (in the Visual Assets section of your Package.appxmanifest file).

segment.source: The default splash screen color is a light gray (hex value \#464646).
segment.target: The default splash screen color is a light gray (hex value \#464646).

segment.source: Note that this Grid element is provided by default when you create a new Blank Page.
segment.target: Note that this Grid element is provided by default when you create a new Blank Page.

segment.source: You don't have to use a Grid; it's just a convenient base for building an extended splash screen.
segment.target: You don't have to use a Grid; it's just a convenient base for building an extended splash screen.

segment.source: Add a Canvas element to the Grid.
segment.target: Add a Canvas element to the Grid.

segment.source: You'll use this Canvas to position your extended splash screen image.
segment.target: You'll use this Canvas to position your extended splash screen image.

segment.source: Add an Image element to the Canvas.
segment.target: Add an Image element to the Canvas.

segment.source: Use the same 600 x 320 pixel image for your extended splash screen that you chose for the default splash screen.
segment.target: Use the same 600 x 320 pixel image for your extended splash screen that you chose for the default splash screen.

segment.source: (Optional) Add a progress control to show users that your app is loading.
segment.target: (Optional) Add a progress control to show users that your app is loading.

segment.source: This topic adds a ProgressRing, instead of a determinate or indeterminate ProgressBar.
segment.target: This topic adds a ProgressRing, instead of a determinate or indeterminate ProgressBar.

segment.source: Add the following code to define Canvas and Image elements, as well as a ProgressRing control, in ExtendedSplash.xaml:
segment.target: Add the following code to define Canvas and Image elements, as well as a ProgressRing control, in ExtendedSplash.xaml:

segment.source: Note This code sets the width of the ProgressRing to 20 pixels.
segment.target: Note This code sets the width of the ProgressRing to 20 pixels.

segment.source: You can manually set its width to a value that works for your app, however, the control will not render at widths of less than 20 pixels.
segment.target: You can manually set its width to a value that works for your app, however, the control will not render at widths of less than 20 pixels.

segment.source: Essential code for an extended splash screen class
segment.target: Essential code for an extended splash screen class

segment.source: Your extended splash screen needs to respond whenever the window size (Windows only) or orientation changes.
segment.target: Your extended splash screen needs to respond whenever the window size (Windows only) or orientation changes.

segment.source: The position of the image you use must be updated so that your extended splash screen looks good no matter how the window changes.
segment.target: The position of the image you use must be updated so that your extended splash screen looks good no matter how the window changes.

segment.source: Use these steps to define methods to correctly display your extended splash screen.
segment.target: Use these steps to define methods to correctly display your extended splash screen.

segment.source: Add required namespaces
segment.target: Add required namespaces

segment.source: You'll need to add the following namespaces to ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs to access the SplashScreen class, Window.SizeChanged events.
segment.target: You'll need to add the following namespaces to ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs to access the SplashScreen class, Window.SizeChanged events.

segment.source: Create a partial class and declare class variables
segment.target: Create a partial class and declare class variables

segment.source: Include the following code in ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs to create a partial class to represent an extended splash screen.
segment.target: Include the following code in ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs to create a partial class to represent an extended splash screen.

segment.source: These class variables are used by several methods.
segment.target: These class variables are used by several methods.

segment.source: The variable stores the coordinates where the system displayed the splash screen image for the app.
segment.target: The variable stores the coordinates where the system displayed the splash screen image for the app.

segment.source: The variable stores a SplashScreen object, and the variable tracks whether or not the splash screen that is displayed by the system has been dismissed.
segment.target: The variable stores a SplashScreen object, and the variable tracks whether or not the splash screen that is displayed by the system has been dismissed.

segment.source: Define a constructor for your class that correctly positions the image
segment.target: Define a constructor for your class that correctly positions the image

segment.source: The following code defines a constructor for the extended splash screen class that listens for window resizing events, positions the image and (optional) progress control on the extended splash screen, creates a frame for navigation, and calls an asynchronous method to restore a saved session state.
segment.target: The following code defines a constructor for the extended splash screen class that listens for window resizing events, positions the image and (optional) progress control on the extended splash screen, creates a frame for navigation, and calls an asynchronous method to restore a saved session state.

segment.source: Make sure to register your Window.SizeChanged handler ( in the example) in your class constructor so that your app positions the image correctly in your extended splash screen.
segment.target: Make sure to register your Window.SizeChanged handler ( in the example) in your class constructor so that your app positions the image correctly in your extended splash screen.

segment.source: Define a class method to position the image in your extended splash screen
segment.target: Define a class method to position the image in your extended splash screen

segment.source: This code demonstrates how to position the image on the extended splash screen page with the class variable.
segment.target: This code demonstrates how to position the image on the extended splash screen page with the class variable.

segment.source: (Optional) Define a class method to position a progress control in your extended splash screen
segment.target: (Optional) Define a class method to position a progress control in your extended splash screen

segment.source: If you chose to add a ProgressRing to your extended splash screen, position it relative to the splash screen image.
segment.target: If you chose to add a ProgressRing to your extended splash screen, position it relative to the splash screen image.

segment.source: Add the following code to ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs to center the ProgressRing 32 pixels below the image.
segment.target: Add the following code to ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs to center the ProgressRing 32 pixels below the image.

segment.source: Inside the class, define a handler for the Dismissed event
segment.target: Inside the class, define a handler for the Dismissed event

segment.source: In ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs, respond when the SplashScreen.Dismissed event occurs by setting the class variable to true.
segment.target: In ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs, respond when the SplashScreen.Dismissed event occurs by setting the class variable to true.

segment.source: If your app has setup operations, add them to this event handler.
segment.target: If your app has setup operations, add them to this event handler.

segment.source: After app setup is complete, navigate away from your extended splash screen.
segment.target: After app setup is complete, navigate away from your extended splash screen.

segment.source: The following code defines a method called that navigates to the defined in your app's MainPage.xaml file.
segment.target: The following code defines a method called that navigates to the defined in your app's MainPage.xaml file.

segment.source: Inside the class, define a handler for Window.SizeChanged events
segment.target: Inside the class, define a handler for Window.SizeChanged events

segment.source: Prepare your extended splash screen to reposition its elements if a user resizes the window.
segment.target: Prepare your extended splash screen to reposition its elements if a user resizes the window.

segment.source: This code responds when a Window.SizeChanged event occurs by capturing the new coordinates and repositioning the image.
segment.target: This code responds when a Window.SizeChanged event occurs by capturing the new coordinates and repositioning the image.

segment.source: If you added a progress control to your extended splash screen, reposition it inside this event handler as well.
segment.target: If you added a progress control to your extended splash screen, reposition it inside this event handler as well.

segment.source: Note Before you try to get the image location make sure the class variable () contains a valid SplashScreen object, as shown in the example.
segment.target: Note Before you try to get the image location make sure the class variable () contains a valid SplashScreen object, as shown in the example.

segment.source: (Optional) Add a class method to restore a saved session state
segment.target: (Optional) Add a class method to restore a saved session state

segment.source: The code you added to the OnLaunched method in Step 4: Modify the launch activation handler causes your app to display an extended splash screen when it launches.
segment.target: The code you added to the OnLaunched method in Step 4: Modify the launch activation handler causes your app to display an extended splash screen when it launches.

segment.source: To consolidate all methods related to app launch in your extended splash screen class, you could consider adding an asynchronous method to your ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs file to restore the app's state.
segment.target: To consolidate all methods related to app launch in your extended splash screen class, you could consider adding an asynchronous method to your ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs file to restore the app's state.

segment.source: When you modify the launch activation handler in App.xaml.cs, you'll also set to true if the previous ApplicationExecutionState of your app was Terminated.
segment.target: When you modify the launch activation handler in App.xaml.cs, you'll also set to true if the previous ApplicationExecutionState of your app was Terminated.

segment.source: If so, the method restores the app to its previous state.
segment.target: If so, the method restores the app to its previous state.

segment.source: For an overview of app launch, suspension, and termination, see App lifecycle.
segment.target: For an overview of app launch, suspension, and termination, see App lifecycle.

segment.source: Modify the launch activation handler
segment.target: Modify the launch activation handler

segment.source: When your app is launched, the system passes splash screen information to the app's launch activation event handler.
segment.target: When your app is launched, the system passes splash screen information to the app's launch activation event handler.

segment.source: You can use this information to correctly position the image on your extended splash screen page.
segment.target: You can use this information to correctly position the image on your extended splash screen page.

segment.source: You can get this splash screen information from the activation event arguments that are passed to your app's OnLaunched handler (see the variable in the following code).
segment.target: You can get this splash screen information from the activation event arguments that are passed to your app's OnLaunched handler (see the variable in the following code).

segment.source: If you have not already overridden the OnLaunched handler for your app, see App lifecycle to learn how to handle activation events.
segment.target: If you have not already overridden the OnLaunched handler for your app, see App lifecycle to learn how to handle activation events.

segment.source: In App.xaml.cs, add the following code to create and display an extended splash screen.
segment.target: In App.xaml.cs, add the following code to create and display an extended splash screen.

segment.source: ExtendedSplash.xaml includes a button.
segment.target: ExtendedSplash.xaml includes a button.

segment.source: When this button is clicked, an event handler, , calls the method.
segment.target: When this button is clicked, an event handler, , calls the method.

segment.source: In your app, call when your app is done loading resources or initializing its UI.
segment.target: In your app, call when your app is done loading resources or initializing its UI.

segment.source: This app also uses a UWP app project template, which uses Frame navigation.
segment.target: This app also uses a UWP app project template, which uses Frame navigation.

segment.target: As a result, in App.xaml.cs, the launch activation handler (OnLaunched) defines a and uses it to set the content of the app window.

segment.source: ExtendedSplash.xaml: This example includes a button because it doesn't have app resources to load.
segment.target: ExtendedSplash.xaml: This example includes a button because it doesn't have app resources to load.

segment.source: In your app, dismiss the extended splash screen automatically when your app is done loading resources or preparing its initial UI.
segment.target: In your app, dismiss the extended splash screen automatically when your app is done loading resources or preparing its initial UI.

segment.source: ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs: Note that the method is called from the click event handler for the button.
segment.target: ExtendedSplash.xaml.cs: Note that the method is called from the click event handler for the button.

segment.source: In your app, you won't need a button.
segment.target: In your app, you won't need a button.

segment.source: Instead, call when your app is done loading resources and you want to navigate to its main page.
segment.target: Instead, call when your app is done loading resources and you want to navigate to its main page.

segment.source: App.xaml.cs: This project was created using the UWP app Blank App (XAML) project template in Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: App.xaml.cs: This project was created using the UWP app Blank App (XAML) project template in Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Both the and event handlers are automatically generated and don't need to be changed to implement an extended splash screen.
segment.target: Both the and event handlers are automatically generated and don't need to be changed to implement an extended splash screen.

segment.target: This topic only modifies .
